PROJECT DESIGN DOCUMENT FORM (CDM-SSC-PDD) - Version 03
CDM – Executive Board
The identified CDM project is being promoted by Vish Wind Infrastructure LLP & Vaayu Infrastructure
LLP. Vish Wind Infrastructure LLP (one of the PP in present Bundle) has previously installed following
three projects in Jamnagar district.
1) Bundled Wind Power Project in Jamnagar, Gujarat (UNFCCC Reg No:4964)
This is a small scale bundled CDM wind power project by the project proponent (Vish Wind
Infrastructure LLP) and J. N. Investment & Trading Co. Private Limited in the state of Gujarat. The same
can be viewed on the UNFCCC website for CDM.
http://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/DB/SGS-UKL1309779882.44/view
The above WECs are located in Jamjodhpur taluka while the present project WECs are located in Lalpur
taluka of Jamnagar District. Therefore, The above location details are at a distance of about 53 km from
the present project machine locations (http://www.distancesfrom.com).
2) Wind Energy Project in Gujarat
This is a large scale CDM wind power project by Vish Wind Infrastructure LLP in district Kutch and
Lalpur of Gujarat. Project is under CDM validation and same can be viewed on the UNFCCC website:
http://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/Validation/DB/IK1BYLA1OA6M6X4NT9D8FKKFF77CQZ/view.html
Though Vish Wind Infrastructure is having another CDM project activity which is under validation in the
same lalpur taluka, the two closest WECs of present project activity and above mentioned project are
located around 12 km from each other.
3) Grid connected clean energy project in Jamnagar, Gujarat
This is a small scale CDM wind power project by Vish Wind Infrastructure LLP in the state of Gujarat.
The same can be viewed on the UNFCCC website for CDM.
http://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/Validation/DB/BNP1KWH4T98RXXRK88MEREP7S0WQOF/view.html
The above WECs are located in Jamjodhpur taluka while the present project WECs are located in Lalpur
taluka. Therefore, The above location details are at a distance of about 53 km from the present project
machine locations. (http://www.distancesfrom.com).
Thus it can be confirmed that the present activity is not a de-bundled component of a large scale project.
This is in line with “Guidelines on Assessment of Debundling for SSC project activities, Version 03, EB
54, Annex 13”. Thus it is demonstrated that the present project activity is not a de-bundled component of
any large scale project activity.

project activities-Annex II of decision 4 CMP.1
B.2 Justification of the choice of the project category:
>>
The Proposed Project activity is a 12.8 MW wind power project. The project activity generates electricity
from wind energy (renewable sources) and the same is exported to the ‘Northern Eastern Western North-
Eastern’ NEWNE grid system, which is presently dominated by thermal energy sources. The Proposed
project activity is well below the qualifying limit of project activities under the small scale methodology
AMS.I.D i.e. 15MW. Hence, AMS.I.D ‘Grid connected renewable electricity generation’, Version 17 is
applied to this small scale project activity.
Requirements with respect to technology/measure under AMS-I D- “Grid connected renewable electricity
generation (Version 17)” are as follows:

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1.3 Project Eligibility
The project generates renewable and clean electricity by using wind power that would otherwise
have been provided by the Northwest China Power Grid (NWPG), which reduces the emissions of
CO from fossil fuel-fired generation in the grid, and falls into the category of the six Kyoto Protocol 2
greenhouse gases.
CDM methodology ACM0002 Version 20.0 “Grid-connected electricity generation from renewable

Project Description: VCS Version 4.1
1 PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Linxiang District is a county-level city in Hunan Province, is managed by Yueyang City. Linxiang
located in the northeast of Hunan Province, is known as the "Gateway to Northern Hunan", is
one of the major rice producing districts in China, has a population about 541,864, and annual
household income of farmers is only CNY 35,5111. The project is located in Central of Linxiang
District, Yueyang City, Hunan Province, China, with a total acreage of 8,366.48 ha for double-
cropping rice. The project activity is designed to construction the cement ditch and reservoir to
realize the reducing of methane emissions by conducting intermittently flooded method instead
of continuously flooded method during the cropping season in Central of Linxiang City.
In the baseline scenario, farmers in Linxiang District use continuously flooded method in rice
paddies with the straw on field as the organic amendment inputs, which means fields have
standing water throughout the rice growing season and only dry out for harvest. However, the
organic matter in rice soil under flooded condition can emit a large amount of methane (CH ) 4
because of anaerobic decomposition. In the project scenario, farmers in Linxiang District
changing from continuously flooded to intermittent flooded condition during rice cultivation. By
controlled the irrigation and drainage according to the needs of rice growth, can save water
resources. On the other hand, multiple aeration during rice cultivation can effectively reduce
methane emissions from soil organic matter under anaerobic conditions.
Emission reductions of this project are generated by reducing methane emissions of
continuously flooded during rice cultivation in baseline scenario. With the project activity, an
estimated amount of GHG emission reduction 7.16 tCO e/ha for rice is expected. Annual 2
average estimation of GHG emission reductions from the project activity is 59,871 tCO e/year, 2
the total GHG emission reductions are 598,710 t CO e during the fixed 10 years crediting period. 2
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral Scope 14: Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use (AFOLU), with an activity category
of Improved Cropland Management (ICM) under Agricultural Land Management (ALM).
Project Methodology: AMS-III.AU Methane emission reduction by adjusted water management
practice in rice cultivation (Version 4.0).

This project anticipates the sequestration of an estimated 498,492tCO2e over its lifetime of 50 years at an estimated average of 9,774tCO2e annually.

1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
The FNL Project is a VCS AFOLU (Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use) project,
Scope 14, and, specifically, it falls under the ARR (Afforestation, Reforestation and
Revegetation) category.
1.3 Project Eligibility
The FNL Project is eligible under the scope of the VCS Program because of his
characteristics listed below:
▪ The FNL Project is an Afforestation Project, so it falls into the ARR Category.
▪ The Project Area was not cleared of native ecosystems within the 10 year period prior to
the project star date. See Map 01, where is evident that already in 2008 the land of the
Project Area (blue polygons) was characterized by degraded pasture (baseline scenario).
Before the starting date the activity practiced was cattle breeding.
▪ The Project is not developed inside a REDD+ program zone (Brazil does not have
REDD+ programs in Mato Grosso do Sul) 1. REDD+ program zones in Brazil are located in
Amazon region. There is only one REDD+ program developed in Cerrado region but is
located in Mato Grosso.
▪ The activities foreseen by the Project did not convert the native ecosystem because the
plantations were made on old degraded pasture areas as shown in the Map 01 below, where
the parcels of the Project Area (blue lines) are highlighted and characterized by a light brown
color corresponding to degraded pasture, compared to the dark green that correspond to
natural ecosystem.
▪ The activities carried out during the Project did not lead to any type of hydrogeological
degradation. None of the planted parcels has been drained (there are no wet land areas in
the Project Zone, as demonstrate in the Map 01).

• Avian impacts – a potential impact to the whooping crane was found. BEPC voluntarily
arranged for offsets to address these issues at significant expense ($240,000) after
lengthy discussions with the Fish and Wildlife Service.
• Wetland / Grassland impacts – Basin included voluntary conservation measures to
offset indirect impacts in its EIS, and this impact was resolved to the satisfaction of

resources were avoided.
Both RUS and WAPA concluded that impacts were minimized at the Crow Lake Wind site and
allowed the project to proceed. The Final Environmental Impact Statement, the WAPA and RUS
decisions in the Federal Register approving the projects, and the letter detailing BEPC’s offsets
were all included as Attachment #1 in the Initial Project Description. In sum, BEPC/PWSD1
complied with all necessary legal and regulatory processes in developing Crow Lake Wind.

Projects Registered (or seeking registration) under Other GHG Program(s)
The Project is not registered or seeking registration in any other GHG Program.
Projects Rejected by Other GHG Programs
The Project has neither applied for nor been rejected by any other GHG Program.
1.16 Other Forms of Credit
Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
The Project is not subject to any other emissions trading programs or binding limits.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit
The Project is currently listed in M-RETs (the Midwest Renewable Energy Tracking System), a
third-party registry created to record the generation of renewable energy MWhs and issues
renewable energy credits (RECs) corresponding to that generation. BEPC has a Qualified
Reporting Entity (QRE) group that reads the meter and reports the number of MWhs generated
each month to M-RETs, which in turn assigns unique serial numbers for each MWh. For the
creation of VCUs, the RECs for which VCUs are being claimed will be retired in M-RETS and the
reason for doing this (VCU creation) will be documented in M-RETS. The retirement of these
credits and subsequent identification of the reason will ensure that those RECs will not be double
sold, and that VCUs can be created with confidence.

A.2. Description of the project activity:
>>
The Sichuan Huadian Xixi River Hydro-electricity Development Co., Ltd. Diluo Hydroelectric Project
(hereafter referred to as the “Project”) developed by Sichuan Huadian Xixi River Hydro-electricity
Development Co., Ltd (hereafter referred to as the “Project Developer”), is a grid-connected hydropower
plant with a run-of-river reservoir in Sichuan Province in People’s Republic of China (hereafter referred
to as the “Host Country”).
The purpose of the Project is to utilise the hydrological resources of the Xixi River to generate renewable
electricity for the Central China Power Grid (CCPG). Total installed capacity of the Project is 100 MW,
consisting of two 50 MW turbines. The annual electricity can be generated by the project in theory is
445,570MWh and it is expected to supply 397,013MWh1 to the grid. The surface area of the full reservoir
is 292000m2, and the power density of the Project is 342 W/m2.
Electricity delivered by the project activity to the CCPG would have otherwise been generated in grid-
connected fossil fuel based power plants resulting in Green House Gas (GHG) emissions in the absence of
the project activity. The project activity therefore, by displacing relatively carbon intensive grid
electricity (primary emission source with a Combined Margin Emission Factor of 0.85285 tCO / MWh2) 2
with renewable hydroelectricity, reduces GHG emission that would have occurred in the baseline.
The scenario existing prior to the start of the implementation of the project activity is same as the baseline
scenario as described above.
The Project will contribute towards sustainable development of the Host Country. Specifically, the
Project:
• Increases employment opportunities in the area where it is located, and Project construction secures
jobs in the construction sector. The Project therefore contributes to poverty alleviation
• Enhances the local investment environment, and therefore improves the local economy
• Diversifies the sources of electricity generation. This is important for meeting growing energy
demands, and transitioning away from diesel and coal-supplied electricity generation
• Makes use of renewable hydroelectric resources
1 Expected annual electricity supply to the Grid = Annual theoretical electricity generation * Effective Power
Coefficient * (1 – internal electricity consumption rate)* (1 – Transmission loss rate) = 445,570MWh * 0.9 *(1 –
0.5%) – (1 – 0.5%) = 397,013MWh.
2 Please refer annex 3 for details

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
1.1.3 Climate Objectives
The project’s climate objectives are to mitigate climate change through measures to alleviate the drivers
of deforestation and forest degradation. The resultant decrease in illegal logging, the recovery of already
degraded forests, and the reduction of forest conversion to other land uses is expected to decrease
emissions and enhance forest carbon stocks over time.
1.1.4 Community Objectives
The project’s community objectives are to strengthen livelihood capitals as defined by some of the Basic
Sustainable Livelihoods Framework (SLF) (Richards 2011). These are: (i) strengthening local governance
through improvements to land-use planning and implementation; (ii) supporting the development of
sustainable economic and livelihoods alternatives through training and technical assistance in agriculture
and fisheries, harvesting equipment, and value chains for poor vulnerable communities; (iii) enhancing
local administrative, leadership capacity and environmental awareness through training activities which
intentionally include women from the communities; and (iv) enhancing social capital through the creation
or strengthening of institutions (corporations, associations, cooperatives).
1.1.5 Biodiversity Objectives
To contribute to biodiversity conservation through long-term improvements and connectivity of dense
natural forest cover and associated structural, compositional, functional and High Conservation Value
attributes, as compared to baseline scenario conditions
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
Sectoral scope 14 – Agriculture, Forestry and Other Land Use
AFOLU project category: Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Degradation (REDD+)
Activity type: Avoiding Unplanned Deforestation.
Project activity type was defined according a decision tree located in the methodology used (REDD-MF,
see section 2.1).
Project is individual, not grouped.

1.1. Summary Description of Project:
The Afognak Forest Carbon Project covers 3,326.5 ha (8,219.7 acres) of adjacent or proximal parcels
located on the North coast (Perenosa Bay/Delphin Bay area) of Afognak Island, Alaska.
In a series of transactions outlined in Section 7, the American Land Conservancy (ALC) and the Rocky
Mountain Elk Foundation (RMEF) acquired the Afognak Carbon project properties and related timber
rights from the privately owned Alaskan Native Corporations (Afognak Joint Venture, Shuyak, Inc., and
Uganik Natives, Inc.) over the period of 2005-2009, with the objective of conserving the land in
perpetuity. As part of these transactions, ALC/RMEF specifically retained the carbon legal title rights
and right of use for the purpose of a carbon emissions reduction project; attached a permanent federal
conservation easement to ensure perpetual conservation management; and transferred the remaining
surface title rights to the State of Alaska.
The Afognak Forest Carbon Project achieves net GHG emission reductions and removals through the
avoidance of emissions due to logging in the baseline scenario. The Afognak properties were being
managed for timber production by the previous managers, with existing or pending logging plans in
place across these and adjacent properties owned by the previous owners. The most plausible
baseline scenario is a clear-cut, timber-harvesting scenario following minimum State of Alaska forest
practice requirements and common practices clearly evident in previous logging on the project lands
and adjacent lands across Afognak Island.
The project scenario is conservation management, wherein the State of Alaska manages and monitors
the properties for the purpose of wilderness and ecosystem protection and enhancement activities
under the terms of the title transfer agreement and federal conservation easement. The project
scenario retains the current native and naturally regenerating logged forests in perpetuity to retain and
sequester carbon on the property.

PROJECT DESCRIPTION : VCS Version 3
PROJECT DETAILS
1.1 Summary Description of the Project
Wilmar Agro Vietnam Company Limited (“Project Host”), a subsidiary of Wilmar International Ltd.
(“Project Proponent” or “PP”), will produce rice bran oil, in Thot Not, Viet Nam. The rice bran is
procured from rice mills locally.
Rice bran quality deteriorates rapidly if not processed into oil and/or stabilized with steam in
pelletized form. In order to stabilize the rice bran, the project host transforms the rice bran into
pellets in the pelletization plant. The pellets will then be processed in the extraction plant to
produce the rice bran oil. The steam used in the pelletization and extraction plant will be
generated using steam boilers.
This VCS project activity involves installation of rice husk based boiler to generate the steam
required in the rice bran collection centre which is located at Thot Not. The Thot Not collection
centre is already in operation since May 2009 with a rice bran pelletization capacity of
700tonnes/day. The project host will expand the plant, where the capacity of rice bran
pelletization plant will be increased to 1,200tonnes/day and there will be a new rice bran oil
extraction plant with a capacity of 800tonnes/day by July 2012. A new 17 MT/hour of rice husk
based boiler will be installed at the plant in addition to the existing 10 MT/hour rice husk based
boiler.
In the project activity, saturated steam of 15 kg/cm2is required for the operations. For the purpose
of this VCS project activity, rice husk will be procured from rice mills located nearby the site (i.e.
within 50km radius).
In the absence of this project activity, fossil fuel (i.e. medium fuel oil or “MFO”) would have been
used to fire the boilers, resulting in CO emissions. In addition, rice husk which is waste from rice 2
mill operations in the region would have been dumped in unplanned ways including into nearby
river, resulting in natural decay and CH emissions. This project activity thus, reduce greenhouse 4
gas (GHG) emissions by avoiding carbon dioxide (CO ) and methane (CH ) emissions from 2 4
combustion of MFO and decomposition of rice husk in disposal sites, respectively. In addition, the
project activity prevents local environmental problems such as river congestion and ecological
damage.
1.2 Sectoral Scope and Project Type
According to the Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) criteria, which is an approved GHG
program as per the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS), the project is in Sectoral Scope 1 – ‘Energy
Industries (renewable sources)’ and Sector 13 – ‘Waste handling and disposal’.
Hence as per the CDM guidelines, as per Appendix B of ‘Simplified modalities for small-scale
CDM project activities), the project activity falls into the following types:
1. Type I (renewable energy projects): Category C (thermal energy for the user)
2. Type III (other project activities): Category J (agriculture).
The project activity is a stand-alone activity and is not grouped with any other project.

The municipality of Itacoatiara has an area of 8,891.9 Km² and an estimated population of 104,046
inhabitants and is considered the third largest municipality in the state of Amazonas (IBGE, 2022). It is
in the metropolitan region of Manaus, about 270 km from the capital through the AM-010 highway, which
is an important axis of regional development because it facilitates the flow of people, goods, and services
throughout the central-eastern portion of the state. It has the third largest GDP of the state of Amazonas,
behind only the municipality of Coari and the capital Manaus itself (IBGE, 2022). In 2022, the municipal
GDP reached the amount of R$2 billion, 43% of these resources were concentrated in the agriculture
and cattle raising sector, 37% in the services sector, and 20% in industry. According to Alho (2009), a
researcher in Regional Development at the Federal University of Amazonas, Itacoatiara is a municipality
with a great potential for growth, a scenario that becomes even more favorable due to its geographical
location, on the banks of the Urubu River, a branch of the Amazon River, which houses a port and makes
its economic dynamics even more powerful.
This opportunity for local development comes from: "the availability of natural resources (rivers, roads,
forests, and land) that can be incorporated into the political-economic development, by big capital, or as
a goal of government action" (Alho, 2009). Also, according to the author, in the international division of
labor, the municipality presents itself as a center of agricultural production, although most of its
workforce is allocated mainly in trade (55%) and industry (41%) (Alho, 2009). The primary sector is home
to only 5% of the formal workers in the municipality, with soybeans and sugar cane being the main
products grown on plantations and properties emerging along the AM-010 highway, which provides
access between the two cities. The extraction of wood, rubber, and non-elastic gums is very

representative of the local economy. Cattle raising is represented mainly by cattle and pigs, with meat
and milk production destined for local consumption and export. Fishing is abundant, and the municipality
stands out as a fishing entrepot, both for local consumption and for export.
Regarding the situation of the roads, it is worth mentioning that the AM-010 highway was completely
asphalted in November 2022, within the period of the state elections, according to local residents. The
improvement in the asphalt reduced by half the time required to travel between Manaus and Itacoatiara
which takes an average of 2.5 hours by car. This reduction in travel time was confirmed by Systemica's
research team, who witnessed part of the work in progress, during fieldwork carried out to produce this
document. This facilitation of traffic on the highway has enormous potential in reducing the costs of
production flow, increasing the flow of goods and services in the regional context, implying an opportunity
to expand the generation of employment and income, with the potential to enable more efficient transport
of the production coming from family farming, of great importance in reducing social and economic
inequalities that affect the most vulnerable rural communities in the Amazon context.
The state production of pineapple, citrus, banana, cupuaçu, and more recently coffee is mostly promoted
by small producers, with some initiatives that already focus on sustainable local development,
associating economic growth, improvement of the quality of life of populations and communities, and
forest preservation. Organic products, low carbon economy, and agroforestry systems have great
potential for strengthening, given the increased environmental awareness of some of these producers
who are moving to abandon culturally ingrained techniques, such as the use of fire to clear cultivable
areas, and the use of chemicals and pesticides for soil correction and to combat pests. There is a
movement towards the use of organic inputs, based on a culture of reuse, such as composting, avoiding
the use of substances that negatively impact the quality of food, and that have great potential for
contamination of the soil, rivers, and fish since fish production is crucial for the subsistence of a
significant part of the riverside and fishing communities that inhabit the entire Amazon basin, as rich in
water resources as in biodiversity. This ability of the municipality of Itacoatiara to attract many strategic
projects that bring the premises of sustainable development is due to the "existence of infrastructure
(port, airport, roads), the proximity to major international consumers and the prospect of new public and
private investments" (Alho, 2009) that reinforce its position of relevance in relation to other municipalities
in the Middle Amazon, having in the future the prospect of becoming a regional pole in the scope of
environmentally and socially responsible projects, capable of attracting investments, reducing
inequalities, improving the living conditions of local populations, such as basic sanitation, and the
absence of public services, high rates of hospitalization for diarrhea and infant mortality.
Although Itacoatiara presents a good economic performance, in 2020, the average monthly salary was
1.8 minimum wage, occupying position 25 among the 62 Amazonian municipalities, which can be
considered small in comparison with the size of the municipal GDP, the third in the state. Considering the
domiciles with monthly incomes of up to half a minimum wage per person, Itacoatiara presented 45.2%
of its population in these conditions, which places it in position 57 out of 62 among the cities in the state.
It has only 19.7% of households with adequate sanitary sewage and only 11.9% with adequate
urbanization, which includes the presence of culverts, sidewalks, paving, and curbs (IBGE, 2022).
According to the Environmental Impact Assessment - EIA - related to the implementation of the Itacoatiara

2.1.11 ProjectActivitiesandTheoryofChange(G1.8)
The project aims to increase the carbon sequestration and contribute to the local sustainable
development by planting the trees and shrubs on the barren land and barren mountains. There
are 10,150 ha of project land to be planted by direct planting. No forest land or wetland was
involved in the project area before the project activity. This project is not located within a
jurisdictioncoveredbyajurisdictionalREDD+program.
The implementation of the project would generate GHG emission removals and improve local
environment through growing of the trees and shrubs, enhance the capabilities of local
communities and residents by providing their relevant technical skills and training, and increase
local biodiversity as a result of establishing a forest. The project activity would converse the trees
to protected forest to reduce the GHG emissions for about 3,197,649 tCO e in 60 years, the 2
averageannualemissionreductionis53,294tCO e. 2
Thesetreespecies include Robiniapseudoacacia, Populus hopeiensis, Pinus tabuliformis, Picea,
Pinus sylvestris, Red Armeniaca sibirica, Dahurian larch, Salix matsudacernegundo, Acer
truncatum, Platycladus orientalis, Pinus bungeana Zucc, Salix matsudana, Chinese Robinia,
Robinia, Acer negundoaurea, Ulmus pumila, Armeniaca sibirica, Prunus davidiana, and shrub
speciesinvolvesShinyleafYellowhorn,HippophaeFructus,KorshinskPeashrub,Cerasushumilis,
RosaxanthinaLindlandClove.
The afforestation mode was mixed planting of trees and shrubs. Land preparation method was
fish scale pits and specification of preparational pits were 60 cm×50 cm×40 cm. The fish scale
pitsshall beexcavatedatthefixedpoints arrangedontheslopesurface. Theexcavatedsoilshall
be trimmed into an arc with height of 0.3 m and top width of 0.2 m Shape the outer ridge and pat
the light steadily; Then above the inside of the pit, the topsoil shall be shovelled and backfilled to
the base of the outer ridge, and the pit surface shall be crushed It can be trimmed into the shape
oflow insideandhighoutside. Aftertheseedlingsareplanted, sufficient watershallbepouredfor
root setting, and the seedlings shall be straightened and compacted before being covered with
soil.Afterplanting,watertimelytoimprovethesurvivalrateofseedlings.
The Project Proponent (PP) conducted workshops at the project sites and demonstrated the
benefitsofplantingtreestoincentivisethevillagersabout carbonsequestration.Capacitybuilding
through workshops is a major part of the project activities of the carbon offset project. The
objective of the workshops was to mobilize and train farmers in the correct method of planting
saplings, management of water and weeding. All the members of the village community were
invited to join in the local stakeholder’s consultation meetings organized by the PP where they
wereinformed about the benefits of improving the treecover in their land holdings. The individual
farmers were asked to formalise the relationship with PP by entering into a carbon offset
agreement. They were told that the project activity would result in generation of carbon credits
and that they would earn carbon revenue from the sale of carbon credits. Thus, carbon revenue
would be additional to their regular income from farm produce. As per the terms of the carbon
offsetagreement,thePPwouldclaimcarboncreditsoutoftheprojectactivity.

Where communal land holding certificates exist, they can be used as proof of landholding rights. Such
certificates were issued for some communal lands during the nationwide land registration and
certification. Where they do not exist, a communal landholding certificate can be obtained. This involves
an elaborate process, whereby the project developer must work with the local entities such as Kebele
leaders, community members, village-level Land Use and Administration Committee, and extension
workers (also called ‘development agents’), and the district (woreda) land administration experts to
demarcate/map the land, designate it as ‘communal holding’, and eventually get a landholding certificate
issued for the designated land. It is a consultative community process that can take weeks or months to
complete. Therefore, pursuing this rather long process makes sense where large communal land parcels
are available for implementing the project – for example – in forest landscape restoration projects.
Transfer of Carbon Rights
Every farmer participating in the program signs a planting contract with the cooperative setting the
conditions of their participation in the program, in which they agree to transfer their rights over
ecosystem services (including carbon) to the cooperative. The contract specifies that the cooperative,
in collaboration with PUR, will provide seedlings, trainings, technical assistance and maintenance
premium to the farmer, while the farmer commits to plant, tend to the trees, and respect the
sustainable timber management plan.

The project start date is October 5th, 2023, the date of signature of the first PAI agreement by the

and the country’s needs and political will for reforestation, the land use is considered highly
competitive once the initial investment hurdle has been solved.

1.16 Other Forms of Credit
Joint Project Description & Monitoring Report: VCS Version 4.0 Emissions Trading Programs and Other Binding Limits
GHG removals generated by this project will not be used for compliance with binding limits to
GHG emissions since such limits are not enforced in Paraguay. There are no emissions trading
programs in place in the country.
Other Forms of Environmental Credit
1.16.1
The grouped project is not being used to create other environmental credits.
1.17 Additional Information Relevant to the Project
Leakage Management
1.16.2
The Forestal Apepu Carbon Project aims to increase the carbon stock of former agricultural land
and implanted pastures through afforestation. Leakage would only occur if pre-project activities
by previous owners would be shifted somewhere else in detriment of natural forests and/or
ecosystems. The risk of leakage is low. As a known fact, to date, previous owners have not shifted
pre-project activities to any other region were deforestation/forest conversion is allowed.
Commercially Sensitive Information
None.
Sustainable Development
The project contributes to the national forest sector by providing proof of concept and
implementation of models aligned to political goals, such as the national plan of reforestation
(Decree Nº 10,147 of 2012), governmental efforts to formalize the biomass sector (Decree Nº
4056/2015), and the contribution to the National Determined Contributions of the country,
where afforestation is highlighted as a prominent measure.
On the other hand, the Apepu Carbon Project will be one of the first to introduce the carbon
component, which will bring about proof of concept and more experience in the region. The
project managers will inform the national authorities of the Project, to avoid any possible double
accounting in the future, and contribute to any governmental efforts in this regard.
Further Information
